headline: Easy All-Purpose Barbecue Sauce
description: You'll want to make big batches of this all-purpose barbecue sauce—it's great on a wide variety of barbecued and grilled foods, like ribs, chicken, or burgers.

video.description: Here's how to make an all-purpose barbecue spice rub and sauce that store well in the pantry and fridge. They're both great on a wide variety of barbecued and grilled foods, like ribs, chicken, or burgers.
video.name: How to Make an Easy All-Purpose Barbecue Sauce and Rub

name: Easy All-Purpose Barbecue Sauce
keywords: barbecue, barbecue sauce, easy, quick, sauce

nutrition.servingSize: Makes about 1 cup of spice rub and 2 cups of barbecue sauce

recipeIngredient: 1/4 cup (60ml) dark molasses, plus more to taste
1 small onion, grated on the large holes of a box grater (about 4 ounces; 115g)
2 tablespoons (30ml) cider vinegar, plus more to taste
2 teaspoons (10ml) hot sauce, plus more to taste
1 teaspoon (5ml) liquid smoke, such as Wright's (optional)

recipeInstructions.text: Combine all sauce ingredients in a small saucepan over medium-low heat. Whisk together and simmer until reduced to a glaze consistency, about 15 minutes (sauce should reduce by about one-third). Adjust flavor with more molasses, vinegar, or hot sauce to taste. Cooled barbecue sauce can be stored in a sealed container in the refrigerator for several months.

review.reviewBody:
Kenji's sauce and rub are pretty well thought out as you would guess.

I have been through the gamut of styles and secret recipes and here's a few guidelines that I follow.


Sugar, salt and spices only in the rub. The herbs (leaf based) don't add much in flavor because most of the flavor compounds are fat soluble and are never released.

Not too much salt.


Error on the side of simplicity on the sauce.

Ketchup and vinegar are the base.

The ketchup probably has most of the sugar you need.

Don't be afraid to jack up the quantity of vinegar way up.

Mix cider and white vinegar. Too much cider overwhelms.

Worcestershire always, but not too much.


Don't use oils or fresh garlic or onions. Use powdered alliums. The real stuff will get a little rancid over time.


Regular chilli powder is a good flavor base. Most powders are peppers, paprika, garlic, onion and a touch of cumin.


Simmer the mixture for a short while but don't overcook.


I use a teaspoon of weak potassium sorbate solution per quart of BBQ sauce, marinara and taco sauce. Without any preservatives you will get mold and yucky yeast if you store more than a month.

Try the rub without the salt and brine the meat before instead.
This way you can calculate the amount of salt you use and use as much rub as you want.
Rather than grate the onion, I roughly chopped it and placed all ingredients in a blender. Saved me some work and got a nice smooth texture
Great sauce and seasoning. I added an extra tablespoon of vinegar for more tanginess and only half the hot sauce due to having sensitive eaters :(
I omitted the salt from the rub so that I can salt separately. This better enables dry-brining a day (or more) in advance.
